On Mon, 2004-01-26 at 14:27, kris@... wrote:
> Quoting Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...>:
> 
>  
> >  >>The CrawlController (which implements Checkpointable) is sent the
> >  >>relevant messages. It propagates these to all components it
> >  >>believes needs checkpointing. Those may further propagate the
> >  >>messages. Any POJO can implement the interface, but that's no
> >  >>guarantee it will be called; there's got to be a chain of
> >  >>intentional calls from the CrawlController down.
> >  >
> >  > For consistency with existing code this should be done with the Event
> > model.
> > 
> > I'm not sure; the checkpoint process will likely need to enforce a
> > stronger sense of ordering than is typical when simply registering
> > for a notification that an event ("checkpoint begun", "checkpoint
> > ended") has occurred. A tighter coupling may be inevitable.
> 
> Ok.
> 
I can't see that this couldn't be achieved with the event model. As far
as I can see is the only difference that the modules register themselves
for a checkpoint event instead of some mechanism that searches through
memory for all objects implementing Checkpointable. In both scenarios a
method will be called on the module notifying that it should do the
checkpoint. Is there something I have missed here?

- john
